herb_001.name: Chamomile
herb_001.description: Chamomile is known for its calming properties and has been used as a natural remedy for centuries.
herb_001.origins: Chamomile originates from the daisy family and has an apple-like scent. Ancient Egyptians valued it for its healing properties.
precautions: May cause allergic reactions in people sensitive to daisies, ragweed, or marigolds.
Avoid during pregnancy as it may stimulate uterine contractions.
May interact with blood-thinning medications.

herb_002.name: Peppermint
herb_002.description: Peppermint is a hybrid mint known for its refreshing scent and cooling effect.
herb_002.origins: Peppermint is a cross between watermint and spearmint, commonly used in traditional medicine.
precautions: May worsen acid reflux or GERD symptoms.
High doses of peppermint oil may cause heartburn or nausea.
Avoid applying essential oil directly to the skin without diluting.

herb_003.name: Lavender
herb_003.description: Lavender is well-known for its soothing aroma and ability to reduce stress and promote relaxation.
herb_003.origins: Native to the Mediterranean, lavender has been used in perfumes, oils, and medicines for centuries.
precautions: May cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
Should be used with caution during pregnancy and breastfeeding.
Essential oil should not be ingested.

herb_004.name: Ginger
herb_004.description: Ginger is a powerful root with numerous medicinal properties, widely used in cooking and herbal medicine.
herb_004.origins: Ginger originates from Southeast Asia and has been used in traditional medicine for over 5,000 years.
usage: Fresh ginger in meals for immune support
precautions: Excessive consumption may cause heartburn or diarrhea.
May interact with blood-thinning medications.
Should be used cautiously during pregnancy.

herb_005.name: Turmeric
herb_005.description: Turmeric is a golden spice known for its potent anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
herb_005.origins: Turmeric is native to South Asia and has been a key ingredient in Ayurvedic medicine for centuries.
precautions: May cause stomach upset in high doses.
Can interfere with medications for blood clotting or diabetes.
Avoid if you have gallbladder issues.

herb_006.name: Echinacea
herb_006.description: Echinacea is a flowering plant often used to boost the immune system and fight off colds.
healthBenefits: Reduces symptoms of colds and flu
herb_006.origins: Echinacea is native to North America and was traditionally used by Native American tribes for medicinal purposes.
precautions: May cause allergic reactions in people with ragweed allergies.
Long-term use may weaken immune response.
Should not be used by people with autoimmune diseases.

herb_007.name: Rosemary
herb_007.description: Rosemary is a fragrant herb with antioxidant and memory-boosting properties.
herb_007.origins: Rosemary is native to the Mediterranean region and has been used in both cooking and medicine for centuries.
usage: Fresh rosemary in meals for added flavor
precautions: Excessive consumption may cause stomach upset.
Essential oil should not be ingested.
May interact with blood-thinning medications.

herb_008.name: Basil
herb_008.description: Basil is a fragrant herb often used in cooking and known for its anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties.
herb_008.origins: Basil is native to tropical regions of Asia and Africa and has been used in traditional medicine and cuisine.
usage: Fresh basil in salads and pasta
precautions: May lower blood sugar levels, so use with caution if taking diabetes medication.
Avoid during pregnancy in high doses.
Excessive consumption may lead to blood thinning.
